utterances: What about the November 5th strategy for both of you, and I'll let you go first, Navarrow.
What I mean by November 5th strategy is a lot of people who have been through an experience of a lifetime with this historic race, what do you do with them on November 5th?
I think it continues to give us an opportunity for them to voice their feelings about what's coming forward, right?
We all personally hope that November 5th is a season of change with Barack Obama.
I think it's all about education.
I think whether it's November 5th or any day thereafter, this audience still needs a place to have their voice shown.

Our greatest audience really resides for the politics section which has exploded as hip hop, and the second greatest is gossip right behind politrics(ph) which has gotten really hot, the politrics(ph) section.
Those are the ideas that are most featured by the audience, that bubbles up the ideas.
Because we don't create content, we frame it.
We have curators as opposed to editors.
Well, gentlemen, thanks so much for coming in.
Thank you for having us.
Thank you for having us.
Appreciate it.
That was Navarrow Wright, Global Grind's president and CEO.
He and the project's founder, Russell Simmons stopped by our offices before the election.
Please don't allow the allegations against me to taint this good and honest man.
Ladies and gentlemen, Roland Burris.
Illinois Governor Rod Blagojevich announcing his appointment of Roland Burris to President-elect Barack Obama's vacant Senate seat.
Studs Terkel, also a Chicagoan, once said Chicago politics are no more corrupt than in other cities, just more theatrically corrupt.
And here to talk about the latest theater is Roger Simon of politico.com.
And I guess you watched that press conference.
What did you make of it?
I did.
Yeah, it was high theater.
Studs was right.
But it was also sad.
I mean, the people of Illinois have gone through quite a bit when you think about it.
In my lifetime - I grew up in Illinois - there have been three governors who have gone to prison.
That's quite an embarrassing record.
And this whole kabuki dance that's playing out in front of the American people, I think it is intentionally embarrassing to the people of Illinois.
I mean, in New York, a governor resigned, Eliot Spitzer, and he wasn't even accused of a crime.
He was just caught, you know, consorting with prostitutes, but he had the decency at least to give up his office.
We're involved in a real constitutional clash between not just the three branches of government, executive, legislative, and judicial, but between federal authority and state authority.

I called it a clash instead of a crisis because I don't think we should be so quick to buy into Governor Blagojevich's argument that he had to do something - he had to make this appointment because otherwise, there would be a crisis because Illinois would have only one senator, and it can't survive with one senator.
Right.
And in fact, in Washington, Senate Democrats said that they wouldn't seat Roland Burris.
Nothing against him personally, but just because he was appointed by Blagojevich.

And then the press conference got even more surreal, at least to people who don't normally go to Chicago press conferences, and when Bobby Rush, Congressman Bobby Rush was in the audience, and he was called up to the podium to make some comments, and then basically accused Senate Democrats of being racist if they denied this African-American his Senate seat.
It's the worst possible argument you want to hear it if you are the incoming president, Barack Obama.
Barack Obama's case to the American people was not, you have to elect me and make me the first African-American president.
And to hear Bobby Rush say, no senator could possibly vote against Roland Burris because it would be a lynching if they did is just not the message that the president-elect wants to send.
And in fact, the president-elect from Hawaii was very quick to issue a very clear and unequivocal statement saying he has nothing against Roland Burris, but Roland Burris should not take this seat.
Rod Blagojevich should resign, and in fact, the Senate should refuse to seat any choice made by Governor Blagojevich.
The Senate has now been given a cover by President-elect Obama to say, look, if President-elect Obama says we can vote against Roland Burris, then I guess we can vote against Roland Burris.
Just on a lighter note, you have a photo up at politico.com of a giant tomb Roland Burris has built in a cemetery for himself and his family, and it's emblazoned with the word trailblazer on it.
Yeah.
And he left room because he was hoping they could also engrave governor on it.
I mean, Roland Burris is not a bad guy in Illinois terms simply because he served three terms as comptroller and one term as attorney general and was never indicted for anything.
He's been out of politics for a while, and you can see from his point of view, this is my way back in.
In retrospect, I think he's going to regret having accepted it.
Roger Simon, senior correspondent at politico.com, always great to talk with you.
Thank you.
Thank you so much.
Another head-spinning week on the Russia beat.
The president's former personal lawyer was sentenced to three years in prison after he implicated Donald Trump in a scheme to make hush-money payments to women during the 2016 campaign.
Prosecutors in New York unveiled a cooperation agreement with the publisher of The National Enquirer, who may have stories to share.
And the investigation seems to have widened to include the funding of the Trump inauguration committee.
Here to discuss all that and more is NPR national justice correspondent Carrie Johnson.
Carrie, thanks so much for being with us.
Good morning, Scott.
Let's, of course, begin with Michael Cohen.
He once promised to take a bullet for President Trump.
Now he's flipped on him.
What's the latest?
Michael Cohen says Trump directed him to take care of payments for two women with whom Trump allegedly had affairs.
The idea, Cohen says, was to influence the election.
Cohen says he had blind loyalty to Donald Trump, but that's over now.
Here he is talking to ABC News this week.
The Armenian resolution is not expected to come up for a vote in Washington this week but there are all sorts of other goings-on.
And to talk about them, we're joined by NPR's senior Washington editor Ron Elving, who joins us every Monday.
Hi, Ron.
Always a pleasure, Madeleine.

Well, President Bush's nominee for attorney general, Judge Michael Mukasey, he goes before the Senate Judiciary Committee for his confirmation hearings beginning on Wednesday, and is it likely to be smooth sailing for him?
Smooth sailing in the sense of confirmation.
But he is going to have a long day on the hot seat, Wednesday.
Most of it is going to be about the past.
And it's not really his past.

It's really Alberto Gonzales' past, and if you will, in general, the Bush administration's relationship with Congress over judicial issues, particularly having to do with the war in Iraq, with surveillance of American citizens.
So it's going to be mostly not about him.

But there will be some discussion of some of the things that he did as a federal judge in New York that involved signing warrants, that involved surveillance, that involved detention, issues that will plug him into the history of the Bush administration on those issues.
But Judge Mukasey is not seen as someone who just, you know, rolls over and does whatever the Bush administration wants him to do, right?
He is seen as an independent mind.
That's right.
And that's why I think, ultimately, he will be approved both by this committee and by the full Senate.

Chuck Schumer, after all, who is one of the most vociferous critics of Alberto Gonzales on this committee, is the senator from New York, has known this judge for a long time and believes that he will be a fair referee, a good umpire, and that, while he's conservative, while he does not share Chuck Schumer's philosophy on many of these issues, he will not, as you put it, roll over for the Bush administration.
All right.
Another contentious issue.
This is the so-called SCHIP.
And President Bush vetoed that.
That is health insurance for poor children, and the GOP, expected to block and override.
Although it will be a contentious road, I understand, which party benefits most from the president's veto?
For the moment, it appears the Democrats surely will benefit because they are in a position that is favored by most people.
Seventy percent tell pollsters that they like this program.
The president has made a gutsy veto.
You can call it that.
You can call it politically foolish.
And he's going to be sustained for the simple reason that there are enough Republicans who are willing to take the political pain with him to sustain his veto.
It takes two-thirds to override.
That means almost 290 votes in the House.
So even though the Democrats pulled 45 Republicans over on the original vote, they need even more than that.
They need 60 Republicans in order to override.
And they're just going to come up short, probably 10 or 15 votes.
So any hope of changing those 10 or 15 votes?
They certainly have been working at it.
People have been in the media.
They have been in the streets over this issue.
They've really beaten them over the head.

But when you get right down to it, there are probably too many districts where a Republican would suffer more politically by opposing the president on this issue by voting to override than even by voting against healthcare for children.
Okay, let's turn to the Republican presidential race.
And, you know, where was Fred Thompson over the weekend?
I was looking high and low for him.
And he just didn't seem to want to come out and play with the other Republicans.
After that debate last week, I think most people expected him to get out on the stump, have a lot of public events, really be in the news, be all over the talk shows.
It didn't happen.
Fred Thompson seems to have pulled back into almost a private campaign mode.
This might make sense if you were the odds on favor to be nominated, if you were cruising to reelection.
But given that he had entered the race when he did, he does seem to be pulling back, reexamining, trying to decide how he wants to go forward.
Who knows?
Maybe he's going to decide that he got in it all too early.
Maybe he was studying his lines for the next ""Law & Order"" episode.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Or for the next debate.
(Soundbite of laughter)
All right.
Ron Elving, senior Washington editor, thanks for joining us.
My pleasure, Madeleine.
(Soundbite of music)
Stay with us on DAY TO DAY from NPR News.
Also in his news conference today, President Bush denied new claims that al-Qaida is stronger than ever.
President GEORGE W.
BUSH: There is a perception in the coverage that al-Qaida may be as strong today as they were prior to September the 11th.
That's just simply not the case.
Bruce Riedel is a terrorism expert and senior fellow at The Brookings Institution.
He recently wrote an article on al-Qaida's strength for Foreign Affairs magazine.
Welcome to DAY TO DAY.
Thank you.
It's my pleasure to be here.
Homeland Security Chief Michael Chertoff said this week that he had a, quote, ""gut feeling"" that there's an increased chance of a summertime attack.
And today he backed away from that comment.
What do you think?
What is the real threat?
